text:
Hey guys,

What do you think about the "Product-led Growth" concept?

I'm asking because of a piece I'm really excited about, where I'm detailing how Product-Led Growth doesn't work exactly as it postulates:

 “...a go-to-market strategy that relies on using your product as the main vehicle to acquire customers...”

My argument is that what really drives SaaS businesses, and is a more reliable vehicle to acquire users is "Product-led storytelling."

In my piece, I examined many SaaS brands and found the same pattern.

I've also detailed how they're driving incredible growth (with stats, results, etc), using "Product-led Storytelling."

Also, I selected these examples from enterprise level, growth stage, and early stage brands.

I found that being a product-led storytelling brand is more reliable to acquire customers than being product-led growth, based on the way it is defined.

My piece is currently under edit.

I'd open to include some answers to the question in my piece (with a backlink, of course :relaxed:)

Thanks.

text:
Hi everyone,

What techniques do you find most helpful for promoting a branded blog to new readers? Do you boost posts on FB? Do you use partner marketing? Do you link previous posts to new posts? Looking for specifics assuming the content is quality and your email list receives updates.

Thanks!

Thanks!

text:
The success of the <http://dispatch.m.io|Mio blog> has been 90% down to organic traffic.

I.e. March saw 250,000 readers, of which over 200,000 were via Google search.

So the technique that has helped the most, personally, is learning every I have about SEO.

attachments.text: Enterprise Messaging News + Insights. Mio powers seamless communication between Microsoft Teams, Slack, and Webex Teams.

text: I’m building a content library and website from the ground up for my 8-month-old startup. Looking for a SERP tracker for a handful of target keywords and pages (less than 20 pages, 100 keywords). In past worlds I’ve used Ahrefs and that’s probably where I’ll go down the road. But at the moment, I’m trying to find a free or under $20/mo tool to help us get off the ground. Any suggestions? Thanks for the help!

elements.text: I’m building a content library and website from the ground up for my 8-month-old startup. Looking for a SERP tracker for a handful of target keywords and pages (less than 20 pages, 100 keywords). In past worlds I’ve used Ahrefs and that’s probably where I’ll go down the road. But at the moment, I’m trying to find a free or under $20/mo tool to help us get off the ground. Any suggestions? Thanks for the help!

text:
Google Search Console if you don't mind periodic data pulls.

or, if you're cool with building something in Google Data Studio, it has an integration there: <https://support.google.com/datastudio/answer/7314895?hl=en>

elements.text:
Google Search Console if you don't mind periodic data pulls.

or, if you're cool with building something in Google Data Studio, it has an integration there:

text:
things we've seen in recent years:

• sign-up to live attendance rates have declined.
• sometimes 50%+ of views are after the fact (on-demand).
• in-webinar activities like polls help with engagement.
• timeliness of the topic has a huge impact on attendance.
• framing the webinar topic to make a post-webinar video resource with acquisition potential extends value (i.e. frame the topic around how people search about that issue).

elements.text: things we've seen in recent years:
sign-up to live attendance rates have declined.
sometimes 50%+ of views are after the fact (on-demand).
in-webinar activities like polls help with engagement.
timeliness of the topic has a huge impact on attendance.
framing the webinar topic to make a post-webinar video resource with acquisition potential extends value (i.e. frame the topic around how people search about that issue).

text: Has anyone come across a really good comms guideline/template or has best practices on how to put one together (i.e. tone of voice, do's/don'ts, etc.)? Building out a more formulaic way to tie brand messaging, content, and writing styles to be as consistent as possible. Could use any insight :pray:

elements.text: Has anyone come across a really good comms guideline/template or has best practices on how to put one together (i.e. tone of voice, do's/don'ts, etc.)? Building out a more formulaic way to tie brand messaging, content, and writing styles to be as consistent as possible. Could use any insight

text: MailChimp has their whole content style guide public that you can use as a template/inspiration: <https://styleguide.mailchimp.com/>

attachments.title: Welcome to the Mailchimp Content Style Guide | Mailchimp Content Style Guide
attachments.text: Guidelines and resources for web writers and editors. Includes: voice and tone, grammar, web style, social media, email newsletters, blog posts, legal content, technical content, accessibility, translation, copyright, and more.
attachments.fallback: Mailchimp: Welcome to the Mailchimp Content Style Guide | Mailchimp Content Style Guide

elements.text: MailChimp has their whole content style guide public that you can use as a template/inspiration:

text:
Yes, definitely. I always end up back at the O.G. MailChimp style guide throughout a comms/content style guide process :joy:

I use two main books when I build these: 1. _Microcopy: The Complete Guide_ by Kinneret Yifrah, 2. More recently, _Writing is Designing_ by Michael J. Metts and Andy Welfle (their chapter on tone is the most robust I've ever seen). _Strategic Writing for UX, Building a Story Brand,_ and _Nicely Said_ are also really helpful books.

I would also check out <https://uxdesign.cc/creating-a-copy-system-along-with-your-design-system-58afd89c3c12|messaging hierarchies> (by Bobbie Wood) plus this  list of <http://uxwritinghub.com/content-style-guides/|14 content style guides>.

attachments.title: Creating a copy system along with your design system
attachments.text: For Google Pay, we needed UX copy that extended from marketing through product, and across surfaces including mobile, web, and voice…
attachments.fallback: Medium: Creating a copy system along with your design system

attachments.title: Top 14 Content Style Guides 2020 (and How to Use Them) -
attachments.text: We've collected the top 14 content style guides for you to use on your next content style guide creation journey. Join the ride!
attachments.fallback: UX WRITING HUB: Top 14 Content Style Guides 2020 (and How to Use Them) -
